comments.commentBody: If everyone else in the sport at the elite level was also cheating, as many accounts suggest, it seems doubtful that he committed any offense against his competitors.

"Noë distinguishes between two kinds of cheating: breaking rules that are constitutive of a game and those which are not. Since Armstrong’s transgressions are of the latter kind, we should judge him differently "

True enough, its much worse. In the first case the cheating is directed at a temporary advantage in one event. In the second, the cheating is a permanent part of that person's participation.

Its impossible to separate any of Armstrong's achievements from his cheating. He was never a champion, he was only a cheater. And he cheated every one of the people who competed fairly against him. He prevented them from winning. His entire career was a lie.
why what happened, We love Bill Clinton and  surely you didn't get what he explained, Apparently your attraction to Democrat party is skin deep.
Yes, he did repeal Glass-Steagall. Why, I'll never know.
That was by all accounts a brilliant speech, and your denial of this say much more about you than it does about Clinton or Warren.

Not so sure it was bad timing. Another way to look at it may be to consider the difference in audiences each event wished to attract.
I should imagine that the people watching the Democratic convention might wonder how anyone would prefer to watch a football game over the convention. While, I can also imagine the possibility that a football fan might consider anyone willing to listen to one speaker after another talk and talk and talk at a political rally to be a bit looney. Neither the twain shall meet. The Obama camaign has alot of smart people workng for him. They have it covered. If people want ther cake and eat it too, we have the technology to watch the game on the big screen, while sneaking a peek at the convention on the laptop.

Nobody but NOBODY warms hearts AND pleases brains like Bill Clinton!!
And he does it with grace, humor and ferocious truth-telling.

Two lines I loved:

"People ask me all the time how we delivered four surplus budgets. What new ideas did we bring? I always give a one-word answer: arithmetic."

AND

"Remember, Republican economic policies quadrupled the debt before I took office and doubled it after I left. We simply can't afford to double-down on trickle-down."

Go Barak and Go Joe Biden!

I wish I could be so celebratory, but I think the claims that we have averted a deeper recession/depression are premature at best. Put party politics aside and look at where our federal and state finances are taking us. Our money supply is expanding at an alarming rate (>20%/year) and our federal finances could and will get far worse if the global financial community turns on the dollar and on US debt.

The Bush/Obama presidencies began the process of recovery and repair by trying to shore up our banking system, and as a part of that effort, Congress forced the banks to reduce risk and improve their balance sheets. As a part of those risk reduction efforts, our banks have invested heavily in US treasuries. I would submit that most banks would prefer not to be so heavily invested in US debt if they had other options, but at the moment, we are a safer haven than the truly awful securities available in places like the EU. That helps to keep our interest rates low...for now. The EU will be making major decisions to begin cleaning up their own sovereign debt issues in the next few weeks. If they succeed, our interest rates will likely rise, taking our federal deficits - not to mention the dollar and our economy - along for the ride. If they are being honest, Bush and Obama are still saying: "we could lose this sucker." If that comes to pass, Bush and Obama did that.

Accordingly, I think a grade of incomplete is an honest assessment of the Obama presidency to date.

You are exactly right, "that sucker didn't go down." And Obama didn't get credit for it.
Similarly, President Obama made the decision to take out Bin Laden. If he had failed, the GOP would have tarred and feathered him. But it succeeded, so they again give him no credit.

Obama's foreign policy (not just the taking out of Bin Laden) has been a smashing success, because the Republicans could do little to get in his way. Imagine what he could have done domestically without their interference?

www.newyorkgritty.net
Reminds me of the headline in The Onion the day after Obama was elected: "Black Man Gets Worst Job in America."

Just before he left office, President Bush was quoted as saying of the US economy, "This sucker could go down." I have also seen it reported as, "We could lose this sucker."

Then Obama had that sucker dropped in his lap, a live grenade with the pin pulled.

Now, we take for granted that we did not lose it, it didn't go down. But Obama did that.
Best articulation of  the Democrats' vision yet at convention. Also utter demolition job of Romney and Ryan. Bravo Bill!
Out. Of. The. Park. The most direct, cogent description of our values, the President's record, his plan and rebuttal of the GOP lies to date. Fired up! Ready to go!
An absolute Tour de Force - thank you Mr Clinton for exposing the truth and doing so in a way that the average American can understand and relate to!

Wrong. History. Arithmetic. Reality.

Invest in broad wealth creation. Bankrupt is what Bush got is and R-R would bring back because they practice zombie plutocratic economics.

Nothing fuzzy about it.  It was as clear as a bell.  It was the truth.  And it was such a relief to hear it.  It was a real feast compared to the cardboard dinners Republicans have been feeding the American public.
Do the math on Romney's tax plan.  Talk about fuzzy.

Reading the comments here, I can't believe people are falling for a fuzzy speech.  The cold hard fact is that the US will go broke and become a third world country if Obama is re-elected.  People should look at the US balance sheet and Obama's employment record rather than fall for Bill Clinton's speech....

Nobody does it better than the man from Hope talking about the man to give us hope. If only we could clone Clinton and Obama to get the best of each of them. Each has something the other needs to make them pperfect. But each is infinitely better than the choice the Republicans are giving us

What a shame to break up the collection.  It will be impossible to reassemble it in the future.  I think the collection should be placed in a museum and parts of the collection could be sent to other museums for short periods of time.

Lego: Seattle is not NYC (as of course you know). Is the main method in Seattle to hail cabs off the street? I'll bet not. Also Seattle has no where the density nor congestion hours in business districts as NYC.

Many people are pro-technology without considering context. As a NYer myself who travels extensively, I so no advantage to this app. I am fine just going out and hailing a cab within 2-3 minutes. I am sure it would take as long if not longer with this complex middle-man service. I think tho this appeals to people who like the "I got mine" competitive system, but that's not me.

Its not such a win-win in NYC. We already have a system here that in general works fine. Just go outside to a curb, and raise you hand and a cab will pass in a minute or so, it stops, you get in and go.
(This is the way it works in general, but in Manhattan it is already usually this simple). I don't need an "app for that."

I actually tried a Mc Donald's vegetarian item last July in Bangalore. Spicy McPaneer (or some such).

It was really bad. Not spicy at all, tasted salty and greasy and one-dimensional. Really a shame when the actual local fast food / street food/ working people;s restaurants are bursting with delicious flavour items. I think people eat McD in India just for the novelty factor, but the local items are 1000X better.

I say this not from any religious point of view, but from the point of view of a rational consumer. McDonald's is the lowest common denominator of bad food just about everywhere. It is a pity that people think this is a high status, high end import.

The rich irony of a Cowboys fan talking about "class", from players to ownership to organization... the Cowboys have lacked class. There are certain things money can't buy... but that won't stop Jerry Jones from trying.

As for the game, Romo took advantage of our third string CB on some key conversions, but let's not rush to anoint him just yet. He did make key plays all over the field, including against our best CB, so I won't begrudge him his numbers, but even so the Giants lost by a TD despite a poor call on the goal line on third down.

Defensively we have a lot of work to do, but it's early yet. I'm not worried. Cruz had a poor game... much more worrisome.

As for rooting for Texas teams... oh right, because you have so many championships right? Be thankful for the Mavs and Spurs.
We know. Republicans stopped paying attention about 30 years ago.
Ask how Bain Capital was doing less than 4 years after he started it.  If Romney didn't have daddy's money, he would never have gotten the second chance you would deny Obama.

Perhaps you should contact your neighborhood billionaire, Mr. Adelson, who's funding Romney to the tune of $50MM. Ask him what he's doing to hire more workers....or why he didn't insist that the Republicans hold their convention in Vegas!
What nonsense!
Listening to Bill Clinton put joy in my heart, tears on my cheeks; the Obama message made clear. Democrats listen, this is serious - get out and vote for our President  one more time!

Really you said so, we the democrats really ignoring that truth.

As big dog said not one can always be right? what part you didn't understand.
Bill Clinton has admitted publicly that that was a mistake he made. It was a Republican idea. He said he wished he'd gotten caught stopping it.
Who cares? He gives a great speech.

Did Bill Clinton apologize for working for and then signing the repeal of Glass Steagall -- the single most important cause of the 2008 crash, and the source of all our subsequent misery? Kinda funny Obama is touting his support, when, if it wasn't for the bank collapse wrought by Glass Steagall's deregulation of the banking industry, Obama's stimulus package would have long ago pushed this country into a strong recovery that would have made his re-election a slam dunk.

You sure are a sore loser.  Obama is far more disciplined than Clinton in his professional and personal lives--a major difference.  Obama has had to sweep up after Bush.  Despite that, we are now creating more jobs per month than when we inherited the mess from Bush.  Obama saved the auto industry and finally got through health care coverage for all.  In the future, Obama care will be viewed as the missing and critical piece of Social Security legislation.  Try to take the long view--

Obama has been setting the path to recovery. He said right off in the very beginning that this was going to be a tough, long recovery.

Sorry that the president doesn't have a magic wand to instantly wave away impatience and general despair. But he's been calm, and the economy will recover and begin to boom in his second term.

Clinton demonstrated tonight how inadequate Obama is as a president. Clinton is so superior to Obama that it's laughable to have the two share a stage. Clinton balanced our budget, Obama has produced record annual deficits. Clinton reduced poverty by reforming welfare. Obama has increased poverty and reduced the middle class by failing to create jobs. Clinton reduced our national debt. Obama increased our national debt at a record pace. Clinton's policies created a robust housing market. Obama's prolonged the housing market by adopting ill advised policies. The list of unfavorable comparisons is endless.

Factchecker.org
"Republicans will find plenty of Clinton’s scorching opinions objectionable. But with few exceptions, we found his stats checked out."

Politifact is not so easy to summarize, but in general, they found Clinton's assertions true or mostly true.

I welcome these results!

Many thanks for the various observations on my critique of President Clinton's entertaining speech.

Kathleen, your concern about "names" and free speech puzzles me. I do indulge in and totally support free speech, and consider the First Amendment the Pearl of the US Constitution, and in no way was I disrespectful to President Clinton.

RDV, you are correct regarding the surplus built up during the Clinton years, during the Dot Com Boom/Bubble with the benefit of a Republican House of Representatives with which President Clinton learned to work superbly. Rescinding Glass-Staegel was a disaster, the social engineering of Dodd and Frank which led to the mortgage/housing crisis was even worse, and the The Bubble burst in 2000; the Bush Presidency did suffer a disruption, 9/11, followed by warfare and the collapse of the housing bubble, and Wall Street 9/15/2008.

Janet, thank you for looking over my shoulder as usual. Note that I used the word; selectivity. That is what all politicians do and Bill Clinton is a superb politician, still. I voted for him in '96 on one single issue, which he did deliver on to his credit, and then disgraced himself not long afterward. He is still a fine orator and as everyone knows he could charm the barnacles off a rusty keel.

Rick, you are evidently privy to information that the Republicans have never published nor specifically proposed so if you have a link to their plans please supply it so that we may all become up to date on the matter.

Having checked the fact checkers PoliFact and FactCheck, I can say they have no big concerns about the Clinton speech (nothing even close to the "Pants on Fire" ratings that both Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan earned last week.)

Here on the NYTimes site, have a look under the Business tab at the series called The Reckoning, which has lots of detailed reporting about how the housing bubble came about and the role of the previous administration, including President Bush himself (''WH Philosophy Stoked Mortgage Bonfire'') , in creating it. Surely you've read about President Obama's attempts to extend mortgage relief to millions of homeowners that have been prevented by Republicans in the Congress.

If you read The Times, of course you know that the Justice Department has successfully prosecuted quite a few financiers successfully for bank fraud, mortgage fraud and ponzi schemes that were part of the crash, but if you are really ''curious'' you can go right to the Department of Justice website: http://1.usa.gov/OVgE0A

As we worked our way out of an even larger national debt (in proportion to GDP) in a few years under President Truman after WWII, I am not overly concerned about the current $16 trillion unless the same policies that tripled the debt in the 80's and doubled the debt under 8 years of GWB (you know, big tax cuts with illusory spending cuts that never really happen) come back.

But wait a minute, isn' t that just what Gov Romney and Rep Ryan propose?

Curious.

President Clinton gave a remarkable and even entertaining speech tonight and as usual he did a terrific salesmanship job which he highlighted with the word, arithmetic. The problem he has with the concept is exactly the same as you have encountered here; selectivity. When you write a piece sans the facts of the matter, most particularly the actual details of the fallout on the American people which has not been repaired, though being President Bill Clinton, as we all are well aware, has a penchant for inventing facts to serve his purposes, both political and personal during his career, he unfortunately still believes he is able to escape responsibility for his inaccuracies.

Conveniently he never mentioned the 25,000,000 real people still unemployed or under employed, the fact that 50% of High School and College Graduates, 2009 through 2012, are unemployed, that 47,000,000 American souls are now dependent on Food Stamps, and that the now official $16 Trillion National Debt is not a matter of consequence. Neither did he address the millions of home owners in distress, the repossessed and the dispossessed and those who fell victim to the machinations of both social engineering to enable mortgages to people who did not have the means to support them, and the Wall Street Banksters. Nor did he mention that no action has been taken to prosecute any of the Wall Street Banksters. Curious indeed.

The Fact Checkers will have lots to do tonight. And I will welcome the results.
